name: Pythagorean trigonometric identity
explanation: The fundamental identity stating that the square of cosine plus the square of sine of an angle equals one, i.e., cos²A + sin²A = 1.

name: Sine rule for triangles
explanation: A formula relating the ratios of the lengths of sides of a triangle to the sines of their opposite angles, expressed as a/sin A = b/sin B = c/sin C.

name: Cosine rule for triangles
explanation: A formula relating the lengths of sides of a triangle to the cosine of one of its angles, given by a² = b² + c² – 2bc cos A.

name: Cosine of difference of angles formula
explanation: An identity expressing cos(A–B) as cos A cos B plus sin A sin B.

name: Cosine of sum of angles formula
explanation: An identity expressing cos(A+B) as cos A cos B minus sin A sin B.

name: Double angle formula for cosine (cos 2A)
explanation: An identity expressing cos 2A as cos² A minus sin² A.

name: Sine of sum of angles formula
explanation: An identity expressing sin(A+B) as sin A cos B plus cos A sin B.

name: Sine of difference of angles formula
explanation: An identity expressing sin(A–B) as sin A cos B minus cos A sin B.

name: Tangent of sum of angles formula
explanation: An identity expressing tan(A+B) as (tan A + tan B) divided by (1 – tan A tan B).

name: Tangent of difference of angles formula
explanation: An identity expressing tan(A–B) as (tan A – tan B) divided by (1 + tan A tan B).

name: Double angle formula for sine (sin 2A)
explanation: An identity expressing sin 2A as 2 sin A cos A.

name: Alternative double angle formula for sine
explanation: An alternative expression for sin 2A using sine and cosine functions (not fully specified in the text).

name: Alternative double angle formula for cosine
explanation: Alternative expressions for cos 2A involving sine and cosine (not fully specified in the text).

name: Double angle formula for tangent (tan 2A)
explanation: An identity expressing tan 2A in terms of tan A (exact formula not fully specified in the text).

name: Power-reduction formula for cosine squared
explanation: An identity expressing cos² A as one half of (1 plus cos 2A), i.e., cos² A = ½ (1 + cos 2A).

name: Power-reduction formula for sine squared
explanation: An identity expressing sin² A as one half of (1 minus cos 2A), i.e., sin² A = ½ (1 – cos 2A).

name: Product-to-sum formula for 2 cos A cos B
explanation: An identity expressing 2 cos A cos B as the sum of cos(A+B) and cos(A–B).

name: Product-to-sum formula for 2 sin A cos B
explanation: An identity expressing 2 sin A cos B as the sum of sin(A+B) and sin(A–B).

name: Product-to-sum formula for 2 sin A sin B
explanation: An identity expressing 2 sin A sin B as the difference of cos(A–B) and cos(A+B).

name: Product-to-sum formula for 2 cos A sin B
explanation: An identity expressing 2 cos A sin B as the difference of sin(A+B) and sin(A–B).

name: Sum-to-product formula for cos A + cos B
explanation: An identity expressing cos A + cos B as 2 cos((A+B)/2) cos((A–B)/2).

name: Sum-to-product formula for cos A – cos B
explanation: An identity expressing cos A – cos B as –2 sin((A+B)/2) sin((A–B)/2).

name: Sum-to-product formula for sin A + sin B
explanation: An identity expressing sin A + sin B as 2 sin((A+B)/2) cos((A–B)/2).

name: Sum-to-product formula for sin A – sin B
explanation: An identity expressing sin A – sin B as 2 cos((A+B)/2) sin((A–B)/2).

name: drawing a circle of given radius
explanation: Constructing a circle using a compass with a specified radius length from a fixed center point.

name: use of straight edge for geometric constructions
explanation: Employing a straight edge tool to draw precise straight lines and line segments in geometric diagrams.

name: use of compass for geometric constructions
explanation: Using a compass to draw arcs and circles with accuracy in geometric diagrams.

name: use of ruler for measurement in constructions
explanation: Applying a ruler to measure lengths and assist in drawing precise geometric figures.

name: use of protractor for angle measurement
explanation: Using a protractor to measure and construct angles accurately in geometric diagrams.

name: use of set square for drawing perpendicular and parallel lines
explanation: Employing a set square to construct right angles and parallel lines precisely in geometric diagrams.

name: co-ordinating the plane
explanation: Assigning ordered pairs of numbers to points on a plane to represent their positions using a coordinate system.

name: representing linear relationships graphically
explanation: Plotting points and drawing lines on a coordinate plane to visualize relationships defined by linear equations.

name: representing linear relationships in tabular form
explanation: Organizing input and output values of a linear function into tables to analyze patterns and relationships.

name: equivalence of slope and rate of change
explanation: Understanding that the slope of a line on a graph represents the rate at which one variable changes relative to another.

name: interpreting start value in linear relationships
explanation: Recognizing the y-intercept as the initial value or starting point of a linear function in real-life contexts.

name: finding point of intersection of two linear relationships
explanation: Determining the coordinate point where two linear graphs meet, representing the solution to simultaneous linear equations.

name: solving real-life problems using two linear relationships
explanation: Applying methods such as graphical, numeric, or mental strategies to find solutions involving two linear equations in practical contexts.

name: application of Pythagorean theorem in right-angled triangles
explanation: Using the relationship a² + b² = c² to find missing side lengths in right-angled triangles, especially in height and distance problems.

name: use of trigonometric ratios in right-angled triangles
explanation: Applying sine, cosine, and tangent ratios to calculate unknown sides or angles in right-angled triangles.

name: locating axes of symmetry in simple shapes
explanation: Identifying lines that divide shapes into mirror-image halves, demonstrating symmetry properties.

name: recognition of images under translation
explanation: Understanding how points and shapes shift uniformly in a given direction without rotation or reflection.

name: recognition of images under central symmetry
explanation: Identifying points and shapes reflected through a central point producing an image rotated 180 degrees about that point.

name: recognition of images under axial symmetry
explanation: Recognizing reflections of points and shapes across a line (axis) producing mirror images.

name: recognition of images under rotation
explanation: Identifying the position of points and shapes after turning them about a fixed point through a specified angle and direction.

name: investigation of enlargements and effects on area
explanation: Studying how scaling shapes by a factor k changes their size and how the area scales by k squared, considering the center of enlargement.

name: center of enlargement in scaling transformations
explanation: The fixed point from which all points of a shape are expanded or contracted during an enlargement.

name: scale factor in enlargements (0<k<1, k>1, k ∈ Q)
explanation: The ratio k by which a shape is enlarged or reduced, where k can be a rational number less than 1 (reduction) or greater than 1 (enlargement).

name: performing geometric constructions 4,5,10,13,15
explanation: Executing specific geometric constructions as numbered in the referenced curriculum, likely involving basic constructions such as bisecting angles or constructing perpendicular lines.

name: performing geometric constructions 16-21
explanation: Carrying out more advanced geometric constructions as specified in the curriculum, potentially involving complex figures or loci.

name: performing geometric construction 22
explanation: Completing a specific advanced geometric construction identified as number 22 in the curriculum resource.

name: solving problems using the sine and cosine rules
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: solving problems using the sine and cosine rules

name: defining sin θ and cos θ for all values of θ
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: defining sin θ and cos θ for all values of θ

name: deriving the trigonometric formulae 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: deriving the trigonometric formulae 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9

name: applying the trigonometric formulae 1-24
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: applying the trigonometric formulae 1-24

name: Irrational numbers
explanation: Numbers that cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers, having non-repeating, non-terminating decimal expansions.

name: Complex numbers
explanation: Numbers composed of a real part and an imaginary part, expressed as a + bi where a and b are real numbers.

name: Division of complex numbers
explanation: The process of dividing one complex number by another, involving conjugates to rationalize the denominator.

name: Equality of complex numbers
explanation: Two complex numbers are equal if their real parts are equal and their imaginary parts are equal.

name: Argand diagram
explanation: A graphical representation of complex numbers on a plane, using the horizontal axis for the real part and the vertical axis for the imaginary part.

name: Modulus of a complex number
explanation: The distance of a complex number from the origin in an Argand diagram, calculated as the square root of the sum of the squares of its real and imaginary parts.

name: Transformations of complex numbers
explanation: Operations that change the position or form of a complex number on the Argand diagram, such as rotation or dilation.

name: Conjugate roots theorem
explanation: A theorem stating that if a polynomial has real coefficients and a complex root, the complex conjugate of that root is also a root.

name: Polar form of a complex number
explanation: A representation of complex numbers in terms of magnitude (modulus) and angle (argument) with respect to the positive direction of the real axis.

name: Products of complex numbers in polar form
explanation: Multiplying complex numbers in polar form involves multiplying their magnitudes and adding their angles.

name: Quotients of complex numbers in polar form
explanation: Dividing complex numbers in polar form involves dividing their magnitudes and subtracting their angles.

name: De Moivre's theorem
explanation: A theorem stating that the nth power of a complex number in polar form can be found by raising its magnitude to the nth power and multiplying its angle by n.

name: Applications of de Moivre's theorem
explanation: Using de Moivre's theorem to solve problems in trigonometry and complex number theory, such as finding roots of complex numbers.

name: Enlargements
explanation: A transformation that increases or decreases the size of a shape by a scale factor, while preserving its shape.

name: Constructions
explanation: The process of drawing geometric shapes, angles, or lines accurately using a compass and straightedge.

name: Antidifferentiation
explanation: The process of finding a function whose derivative is the given function, also known as finding the indefinite integral.

name: Integrating exponential functions
explanation: The process of finding the integral of functions involving the exponential function e^x.

name: Integrating trigonometric functions
explanation: The process of finding the integral of functions involving trigonometric functions such as sin(x), cos(x), and tan(x).

name: Applications of integration
explanation: Using integration to solve problems in various contexts, such as finding areas under curves and solving physical problems.

name: Definite integrals
explanation: The integral of a function over a specific interval, giving the area under the curve between two points.

name: Finding areas by integration
explanation: The method of calculating the area under a curve or between curves by evaluating the definite integral of a function.

name: Average value of a function
explanation: The value that represents the average output of a function over a specific interval, calculated using integration.

name: Integrating exponential and trigonometric functions
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: Integrating exponential and trigonometric functions

name: Natural numbers (N)
explanation: The set of natural numbers, which includes all positive integers starting from 1, i.e., N = {1, 2, 3, 4...}.

name: Integers (Z)
explanation: The set of integers, which includes all whole numbers, both positive and negative, as well as zero.

name: Rational numbers (Q)
explanation: The set of rational numbers, which can be expressed as the quotient of two integers, where the denominator is not zero.

name: Operations with natural numbers
explanation: The basic arithmetic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division) performed within the set of natural numbers.

name: Operations with integers
explanation: The basic arithmetic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division) performed within the set of integers, including negative numbers.

name: Operations with rational numbers
explanation: The basic arithmetic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division) performed within the set of rational numbers.

name: Negative number operations
explanation: The rules and properties governing arithmetic operations involving negative numbers, often contextualized in real-life scenarios.

name: Properties of arithmetic
explanation: The fundamental properties that govern arithmetic operations, including commutative, associative, and distributive laws.

name: Order of operations
explanation: The rules that dictate the sequence in which operations should be performed in mathematical expressions, often remembered by the acronym PEMDAS (Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication and Division, Addition and Subtraction).

name: Number line representation
explanation: Using a number line to visually represent the order and relationships between natural numbers, integers, rational numbers, and real numbers.

name: Argand diagram representation
explanation: A graphical representation of complex numbers on a two-dimensional plane, where the x-axis represents the real part and the y-axis represents the imaginary part.

name: Complex conjugate
explanation: The complex conjugate of a complex number a + bi is a - bi, which reflects the number across the real axis in the Argand diagram.

name: Prime factorization
explanation: The expression of a number as a product of its prime factors, which are the prime numbers that multiply together to yield the original number.

name: Scientific notation
explanation: A way of expressing non-zero positive rational numbers in the form a x 10^n, where n is an integer and 1 ≤ a < 10.

name: Arithmetic sequences
explanation: A sequence of numbers in which the difference between consecutive terms is constant, known as the common difference.

name: Geometric sequences
explanation: A sequence of numbers where each term after the first is found by multiplying the previous term by a fixed, non-zero number called the common ratio.

name: Sum of n terms of an arithmetic series
explanation: The formula used to calculate the sum of the first n terms of an arithmetic sequence, given by S_n = n/2 * (2a + (n-1)d), where a is the first term and d is the common difference.

name: Rules for indices
explanation: The set of mathematical rules that govern the operations of exponents, including multiplication, division, and powers of powers.

name: Logarithmic properties
explanation: The rules that describe the relationship between logarithms and exponents, including properties for multiplication, division, and powers.

name: Percentage calculations
explanation: The process of calculating a portion of a whole expressed as a fraction of 100, commonly used in financial contexts and comparisons.

name: Ratio and proportion
explanation: The relationship between two quantities, expressed as a ratio, and the concept of proportion, which states that two ratios are equivalent.

name: Surface area of solids
explanation: The total area that the surface of a three-dimensional object occupies, calculated differently depending on the shape of the solid.

name: Volume of solids
explanation: The amount of space occupied by a three-dimensional object, measured in cubic units, with specific formulas for different shapes.

name: Sum of finite and infinite geometric series
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: Sum of finite and infinite geometric series

name: Number systems (N, Z, Q, R)
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: Number systems (N, Z, Q, R)

name: natural numbers
explanation: The set of whole positive numbers starting from 1 and increasing by increments of 1, e.g., 1, 2, 3, ...
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: integers
explanation: The set of whole numbers including positive numbers, negative numbers, and zero, e.g., ..., -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, ...
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: rational numbers as fractions
explanation: Numbers that can be expressed as the ratio of two integers where the denominator is not zero, including fractions like 1/2, -3/5, and integers as fractions with denominator 1.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: rational numbers as terminating or repeating decimals
explanation: Decimals that either terminate or repeat a pattern indefinitely, which can be expressed as fractions of integers.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: surd simplification by factorization
explanation: The process of simplifying surds by expressing the radicand as a product of a perfect square and another factor, e.g., √18 = 3√2.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: constructing line segment of length √2 on number line
explanation: Using geometric constructions, such as right-angled triangles and Pythagoras’ theorem, to represent irrational lengths on the number line.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: imaginary unit i
explanation: The imaginary unit defined as the square root of -1, satisfying i² = -1, used to extend the real number system to complex numbers.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: imaginary numbers
explanation: Numbers expressed as a real number multiplied by the imaginary unit i, representing square roots of negative real numbers, e.g., 3i, -4i.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Numbers expressed as the sum of a real part and an imaginary part, in the form a + bi, where a and b are real numbers.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: real part of a complex number
explanation: The real component a of a complex number a + bi, representing its horizontal coordinate in the complex plane.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: imaginary part of a complex number
explanation: The coefficient b of the imaginary unit i in a complex number a + bi, representing its vertical coordinate in the complex plane.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: addition of complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Adding complex numbers by separately adding their real parts and their imaginary parts, e.g., (a + bi) + (c + di) = (a + c) + (b + d)i.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: subtraction of complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Subtracting complex numbers by separately subtracting their real parts and their imaginary parts, e.g., (a + bi) - (c + di) = (a - c) + (b - d)i.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: multiplication of complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Multiplying complex numbers using distributive property and the fact that i² = -1, e.g., (a + bi)(c + di) = (ac - bd) + (ad + bc)i.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: division of complex numbers by real numbers
explanation: Dividing a complex number by a real number by dividing both the real and imaginary parts by that number.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: multiplying a complex number by its conjugate
explanation: The product of a complex number and its conjugate is a real number equal to a² + b², where the complex number is a + bi.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: division of complex numbers using conjugates
explanation: Dividing complex numbers by multiplying numerator and denominator by the conjugate of the denominator to obtain a real denominator.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: multiplying a complex number by a real scalar
explanation: Scaling a complex number by multiplying both its real and imaginary parts by a real number, resulting in stretching or contraction in the Argand plane.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: reflection of a complex number through the origin
explanation: Multiplying a complex number by -1, which reverses its direction in the Argand plane, reflecting it through the origin.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Slope function
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: Slope function
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Tangents – Increasing and decreasing functions
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: Tangents – Increasing and decreasing functions
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Definite integral
explanation: A definite integral calculates the area under a curve between two specified limits, providing a numerical value representing that area.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Indefinite integral
explanation: An indefinite integral represents a family of functions and includes a constant of integration, indicating the general form of antiderivatives.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Limits of integration
explanation: The limits of integration are the specific values that define the interval over which a definite integral is calculated.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Area under a curve
explanation: The area under a curve is the total space enclosed between the curve and the x-axis over a specified interval, often calculated using integration.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Slope of a tangent
explanation: The slope of a tangent to a curve at a given point is the derivative of the function at that point, representing the instantaneous rate of change.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Stationary points
explanation: Stationary points on a curve are points where the derivative is zero, indicating potential local maxima, minima, or points of inflection.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Local maximum point
explanation: A local maximum point is a stationary point where the function value is greater than the values of the function in its immediate vicinity.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Local minimum point
explanation: A local minimum point is a stationary point where the function value is less than the values of the function in its immediate vicinity.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Point of inflection
explanation: A point of inflection is a point on a curve where the concavity changes, which can be identified when the second derivative is zero and changes sign.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Second derivative test
explanation: The second derivative test is a method used to determine the nature of stationary points by analyzing the sign of the second derivative at those points.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Rates of change
explanation: Rates of change represent how a quantity changes with respect to another quantity, often expressed as derivatives in calculus.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Chain rule
explanation: The chain rule is a formula for computing the derivative of the composition of two or more functions, allowing for the differentiation of complex functions.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Compound interest
explanation: Compound interest is the interest calculated on the initial principal and also on the accumulated interest from previous periods, leading to exponential growth.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Present value
explanation: Present value is the current worth of a future sum of money or stream of cash flows, discounted at a specific interest rate.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Future value
explanation: Future value is the amount of money that an investment will grow to over a period of time at a specified interest rate.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Straight line depreciation
explanation: Straight line depreciation is a method of allocating the cost of a tangible asset over its useful life by deducting a constant amount each year.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Reducing balance depreciation
explanation: Reducing balance depreciation is a method where the depreciation expense is calculated as a fixed percentage of the book value of the asset each year.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Instalment savings
explanation: Instalment savings involve regularly depositing a fixed amount of money into a savings account, which earns compound interest over time.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Probability distribution
explanation: A probability distribution describes how the probabilities are distributed over the values of a random variable, indicating the likelihood of each outcome.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Expected value
explanation: Expected value is the average of all possible outcomes of a random variable, weighted by their probabilities, providing a measure of the center of the distribution.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Tree diagram
explanation: A tree diagram is a visual representation of all possible outcomes of a probability experiment, where each branch represents a different outcome.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Scatter Diagrams
explanation: Graphs consisting of points plotted on an x-y plane representing the values of two different variables.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Bivariate Data
explanation: Data connecting two variables, often represented in scatter diagrams to analyze the relationship between them.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Linear Relationship
explanation: A type of relationship between two variables where the points on a scatter graph lie approximately on a straight line, indicating a direct proportionality between the variables.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Correlation
explanation: The measure of the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two quantitative variables.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Correlation Coefficient
explanation: A numerical measure that quantifies the degree of correlation between two variables, ranging from -1 to 1.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Line of Best Fit
explanation: A straight line drawn through the center of a group of data points plotted on a scatter diagram, which best expresses the relationship between those points.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Positive Correlation
explanation: A correlation where as one variable increases, the other variable also increases.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Negative Correlation
explanation: A correlation where as one variable increases, the other variable decreases.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Causal Relationship
explanation: A relationship between two variables where a change in one variable causes a change in another variable.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: No Correlation
explanation: A situation where there is no apparent linear relationship between two variables.
source: 92_Texts and tests 5 Content Manual Redact_Exercises_Examples copy_extracted.txt

name: Double angle formula for cosine
explanation: An identity expressing cos 2A as cos² A minus sin² A.

name: Double angle formula for sine
explanation: An identity expressing sin 2A as 2 sin A cos A.

name: Double angle formula for tangent
explanation: An identity expressing tan 2A as 2 tan A / (1 - tan² A).

name: Cosine of double angle formula
explanation: An identity expressing cos 2A as ½ (1 + cos 2A).

name: Sine of double angle formula
explanation: An identity expressing sin 2A as ½ (1 - cos 2A).

name: Sum-to-product identities for cosine
explanation: An identity relating the sum of cosines to the product of cosines, expressed as cos A + cos B = 2 cos((A+B)/2) cos((A-B)/2).

name: Difference-to-product identities for cosine
explanation: An identity relating the difference of cosines to the product of sines, expressed as cos A - cos B = -2 sin((A+B)/2) sin((A-B)/2).

name: Sum-to-product identities for sine
explanation: An identity relating the sum of sines to the product of sines, expressed as sin A + sin B = 2 sin((A+B)/2) cos((A-B)/2).

name: Difference-to-product identities for sine
explanation: An identity relating the difference of sines to the product of cosines, expressed as sin A - sin B = 2 cos((A+B)/2) sin((A-B)/2).

name: Cosine squared in terms of cosine double angle
explanation: An identity expressing cos² A as ½ (1 + cos 2A).

name: Sine squared in terms of cosine double angle
explanation: An identity expressing sin² A as ½ (1 – cos 2A).

name: Product to sum formula for cosine-cosine
explanation: An identity expressing 2 cos A cos B as the sum of cos(A+B) and cos(A–B).

name: Product to sum formula for sine-cosine
explanation: An identity expressing 2 sin A cos B as the sum of sin(A+B) and sin(A–B).

name: Product to sum formula for sine-sine
explanation: An identity expressing 2 sin A sin B as the difference of cos(A–B) and cos(A+B).

name: Product to sum formula for cosine-sine
explanation: An identity expressing 2 cos A sin B as the difference of sin(A+B) and sin(A–B).

name: Sum to product formula for cosine sum
explanation: An identity expressing cos A + cos B as 2 cos((A+B)/2) cos((A–B)/2).

name: Sum to product formula for cosine difference
explanation: An identity expressing cos A – cos B as –2 sin((A+B)/2) sin((A–B)/2).

name: Sum to product formula for sine sum
explanation: An identity expressing sin A + sin B as 2 sin((A+B)/2) cos((A–B)/2).

name: Sum to product formula for sine difference
explanation: An identity expressing sin A – sin B as 2 cos((A+B)/2) sin((A–B)/2).

name: circle drawing with given radius
explanation: Constructing a circle using a compass with a specified radius from a given center point.

name: use of straight edge in geometric constructions
explanation: Employing a straight edge tool to draw precise straight lines in geometric diagrams.

name: use of compass in geometric constructions
explanation: Using a compass to draw arcs and circles accurately in geometric constructions.

name: use of ruler in geometric constructions
explanation: Applying a ruler to measure lengths and draw straight lines with precision.

name: use of protractor in geometric constructions
explanation: Using a protractor to measure and construct specific angles accurately.

name: use of set square in geometric constructions
explanation: Employing a set square to draw perpendicular and parallel lines and specific angles like 30°, 45°, and 60°.

name: coordinate plane plotting
explanation: Assigning points on a two-dimensional plane using ordered pairs (x, y).

name: linear relationships in tabular form
explanation: Representing linear relationships between variables using tables of values.

name: linear relationships in graphical form
explanation: Representing linear relationships between variables by plotting points and drawing straight lines on a graph.

name: slope as rate of change
explanation: Understanding the slope of a line as the rate at which the dependent variable changes with respect to the independent variable.

name: start value in linear relationships
explanation: The initial value or y-intercept of a linear function representing the value when the independent variable is zero.

name: point of intersection of two linear relationships
explanation: The coordinate point where two linear graphs meet, representing the solution to the system of equations.

name: strategies for solving two linear relationships
explanation: Using graphical, numerical, or mental methods to find solutions to problems involving up to two linear equations.

name: identification of axes of symmetry in simple shapes
explanation: Locating lines that divide shapes into mirror-image halves.

name: enlargement with centre of enlargement and scale factor
explanation: Transforming shapes by expanding or contracting them from a fixed point using a rational scale factor k, where k can be less than 1 or greater than 1.

name: effect of enlargement on area
explanation: Investigating how the area of a shape changes when it is enlarged by a scale factor k, noting that area changes by a factor of k².

name: logic terms in geometry: theorem, proof, axiom, corollary, converse, implies
explanation: Understanding foundational logical terms used in geometric reasoning and deductive proofs.

name: logic terms: is equivalent to, if and only if, proof by contradiction
explanation: Using advanced logical expressions and proof techniques to establish geometric truths.

name: proof of theorems concerning ratios in geometry
explanation: Demonstrating geometric theorems that involve ratios of line segments or areas, foundational for Pythagoras' theorem.

name: use of slope to determine parallelism of lines
explanation: Showing that two lines are parallel if and only if their slopes are equal.

name: use of slope to determine perpendicularity of lines
explanation: Showing that two lines are perpendicular if the product of their slopes is -1.

name: proof of the theorem of Pythagoras
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: proof of the theorem of Pythagoras
